node.title: Nicoletta Stame and Francesco Pisarri: Proletarians and health (1977) – Chapter One
node.excerpt: A book about the autonomous workers’ committee at the university clinic in Rome in the 1970s, bringing together medical students and porters, workers and patients.

node.title: Nicoletta Stame and Francesco Pisarri: Proletarians and Health (1977) – Intro
node.excerpt: This book documents an inquiry into a recent struggle against class medicine and for the proletarian management of a hospital in which the workers on the Policlinico Umberto I in Rome have been involved in since 1971.

node.title: Struggles in the 1970s at the polyclinic in Rome – Part 1
node.excerpt: The collective’s outstanding character was based on the fact that it included medical students, nurses, porters and doctors, and aimed at the socialisation of the divided knowledge within a project of workers’ control of the clinic.

node.title: NHS pay dispute from below – Online newsletter no.4 / 2021
node.excerpt: Welcome to the fourth newsletter for a worker-led pay dispute from below…

node.title: NHS pay dispute from below – Online newsletter no.3 / 2021
node.excerpt: Welcome to the third newsletter for a workers-led NHS pay dispute!

node.title: NHS pay dispute from below – Online newsletter no.2 / 2021
node.excerpt: Welcome to the second newsletter for a workers-led NHS pay dispute!

node.title: NHS pay dispute from below – Online newsletter no.1 / 2021
node.excerpt: Analysis and intervention in the debate during the pay dispute in 2021/22.

node.title: Leaflet from France/Belgium
node.excerpt: Wo document a leaflet written by friends in France and Czech Republic.

node.title: NHS protest, 15th of May 2021
node.excerpt: Leaflet written for the NHS pay campaign in 2021.

node.title: Fellow health workers – We have to take this struggle into our own hands
node.excerpt: Leaflet written for the NHS pay campaign of action in July 2021.

node.title: Militant inquiry into the ‘white factory’ (hospital) – Part one – Wildcat April 1988
node.excerpt: We translated this article as a general framework for discussion. In 1988 comrades in Germany were inspired, in part by the nurses strikes in the USA and the UK during the same year.

node.title: French lessons – What we can learn from the 1988 hospital workers’ strike coordinations in France
node.excerpt: We translated the following two texts from 1988, because we think that there are still things we can learn from the strike movement back then.

node.title: Hospital workers’ assemblies in Germany – Organising in the “White Factory”
node.excerpt: We translated this text from the late 1980s because it can still serve as a reference-point when searching for new ways that we can organise ouselves as health workers from the bottom up, rather than waiting for orders from the top.

node.title: Review of ‘Memoirs of a callous picket’, by Jonathan Neale
node.excerpt: It is a short and readable book, full of useful and interesting information about the wider social and political context in which NHS nurses went on strike in 1982.

node.title: Debate on the current character of hospitals and their restructuring
node.excerpt: Friends from France have written a detailed paper on the question – read it here.

node.title: ’Fragmented Discontent’ in the hospitals
node.excerpt: (We translated this article about the current situation and recent struggles in hospitals in Germany for the discussion here in the UK

node.title: ‘Hospital and Emancipation’, By Nadja Rakowitz
node.excerpt: Left politics, which claims to represent a democratic perspective that goes beyond capitalism, cannot be satisfied with the goal of merely redistributing the social wealth generated under capitalist conditions.

node.title: Missed chances – Report from the annual meeting of the Unison Health Service Group
node.excerpt: During the last week of April I participated as a delegate of my Unison branch of a local NHS Trust in this annual meeting that brings together all Unison reps in the private and public health sector.

node.title: Warning signals – The UNISON Scotland sell-out of the NHS workers’ pay campaign
node.excerpt: UNISON Scotland recommended their members in the NHS to accept a 4% pay offer of the Scottish government. This is a stab in the back.

node.title: Example of action of ITU nurses resulting in better pay for bank staff
node.excerpt: The action of the ICU nurses show that management reacts to collective pressure from below, even if only a small group of workers are involved.

node.title: Whose strike is it? – Interview with mental health nurse and RCN member
node.excerpt: Interview with a registered mental health nurse in the UK who works in South East England in an NHS community mental health and addictions service.

node.title: Thoughts after the first round of NHS strikes
node.excerpt: The fact that, after three decades, nurses have gone on strike again in the UK is positive, at the same time we need to have a careful look at the weak points of the strike in order to learn for the future.

node.title: Learning from health workers in Argentina – On the current rebellion in Neuquén
node.excerpt: What started as a health workers’ dispute has turned into a regional uprising. Since early March 2021, health workers throughout the province of Neuquén in Argentina have been staging unofficial strikes and roadblocks, demanding a pay rise higher than the miserable deal agreed by the government and the unions.

node.title: Paperwork nightmare – A creative way to strike by emergency services in Germany
node.excerpt: A form of labour dispute – while the collective bargaining dispute was on paramedics refused to do the bureaucratic work that is necessary for the billing of services (e.g. with health insurance companies).

node.title: “We don’t need applause, we need change!” – Interview with a striking nurse in Berlin
node.excerpt: On the 23rd of August 2021, workers of the Berlin hospitals Charité and Vivantes went on a three-day warning strike. The strike included the outsourced service workers at Vivantes.

node.title: The experience of the Nurses’ Initiative in Czech Republic
node.excerpt: The Nurses’ Initiative has been operating in the Karlovy Vary Regional Hospital (KKN) for a year and a half. The nurses’ initiative grew out of KKN workers’ realization in January 2017 that no one would stand up for us.

node.title: Updates after recent staffing disputes at hospitals in Germany
node.excerpt: In Germany we have seen hospital workers going on strike over staffing levels – initially in the two biggest hospitals in Berlin, then more recently in six university clinics in North-Rhine Westphalia.

node.title: “Strikes have to be able to emancipate” – What are the results of the Berlin health workers strikes of 2021
node.excerpt: The strike in the state-owned Berlin hospitals 2021 will go down in the history of the hospital movement for its length of more than 30 days alone.

node.title: Interview – NHS walk-in clinic worker
node.excerpt: Interview with a worker in an acute medicine walk-in clinic in a hospital in England about the situation during Covid.

node.title: Interview with a community midwife
node.excerpt: This interview reveals, amongst other things, the amount of unpaid overtime worked in the NHS during Covid and the transformation of ‘professional online forums’ into channels to discuss working conditions during the lockdown.

node.title: The struggle for better staffing levels in hospitals – UK nurse interview and a response from Germany
node.excerpt: The struggle for better staffing levels is a struggle against stress, burnout, bitching and bad vibes amongst colleagues and against the neglect of patients.

node.title: Test PDF post
node.excerpt: This is a PDF

node.title: HCA philosophy – For a new relation with patients
node.excerpt: Sometimes the hospital is overwhelming. It is like a massive waiting room of social crisis.

node.title: Minimum wages for maximum stress
node.excerpt: Since the pay dispute in 2022/2023, there have been a number of local strikes across the country within the NHS.

node.title: The Letting Game – Letting you down
node.excerpt: Have you tried to sleep after a night-shift with a toddler in the room?!

node.title: On placements and Displacements: Pleasure or Placements?
node.excerpt: Often the work from nursing and medical students guarantees that the ward is ticking over. And what do they get in return for working 12-hour shifts?

node.title: Against the global trauma ward! Not one man, woman, penny, or paramedic for the bosses’ wars!
node.excerpt: Over the next 10 years, the Government has committed to spending an extra £230 billion on weapons and military equipment, while the NHS is told to tighten its belt and more and more of it are auctioned to the highest bidder.

node.title: Daily grind, daily solidarity  – On open and hidden struggle Re-banding or banding together?
node.excerpt: We are all thrown into a mix of long hours, while being short staffed, with colleagues we might not know that well and decisions that affect us, but that we have little control over.

node.title: International nurses – For global links between workers Bye, bye Dubai – Hello Bedminster!
node.excerpt: Health workers are often at the forefront of movements against war and state violence.

node.title: For workers’ and patients’ control of the health industry
node.excerpt: There are good reasons why we need more workers’ and patients’ control over the health system. The pandemic was a prime example. We were able to see how disorganised the system is and how different players just followed their own interests.

node.title: Working Life – Short staffed and short changed? Scrub notes against burn-out
node.excerpt: “Have you got itchy feet…?” – Get your fungal cream out and fight to change things together!

node.title: Vital Signs – A health worker magazine for a new society
node.excerpt: The following is an introduction to the project, its aims and its politics.
